n.Vendors: IBM; IPsoft
n.Definition: Artificial intelligence appears to emulate human performance (typically by learning, coming to their own conclusions, appearing to understand complex content, engaging in natural dialogues with people, enhancing human intelligence � cognitive computing, or replacing people on performance of nonroutine tasks). Applications include automatic speech recognition and generation and detecting novel concepts and abstractions (useful for detecting potential new risks and helping humans quickly understand very large bodies of ever-changing information).
n.Name: ArtificialIntelligence

n.Vendors: Accenture; CSC; Ebix; Munich Re; RGA; StoneRiver; Swiss Re Group
n.Definition: Automated underwriting solutions use a combination of underwriting rules, integrated evidence data (e.g., laboratory reports, doctors' records and medical information bureau reports) and case management features to determine the appropriate rate class for a particular insured person, and to support interactions with human underwriters and case managers. Industry Analyst changed the name from electronic underwriting to automated underwriting to reflect a market-centric name, and to be inclusive of automation features in robust underwriting workbenches.
n.Name: AutomatedUnderwritingSolutions

n.Vendors: GE Intelligent Platforms; Google; IBM Watson; IPsoft; Wipro
n.Definition: Cognitive-enabled services are business or IT service offerings that leverage higher order smart-machine technology platforms that can autonomously understand, learn and solve problems. This category of smart-machine-enabled services complements two others, namely adaptable automation and intelligent-process autonomic services.
n.Name: Cognitive-EnabledServices(Smart-Machine-EnabledServices)

n.Vendors: Almawave; Avaya; CallMiner; Genesys; HP (Autonomy); Interactive Intelligence; Mattersight; Nexidia; Nice Systems; Ramp; Raytheon BBN Technologies; Verint Systems
n.Definition: Interaction analytics solutions provide a holistic understanding of customer-agent interactions through the analysis of multiple data streams associated with the interaction. The data analyzed includes the dialogue (that is, the audio or text, such as email or Web chat), call fSmall dynamics (such as speaking at the same time or pauses in conversation), emotion (customer and agent), operations (such as call length, transfers or Web chat durations), screen (that is, agent desktop activity) and customer feedback (via survey data).
n.Name: CustomerEngagementCenterInteractionAnalytics

n.Vendors: Enter Vendors
n.Definition: A distributed autonomous organization (DAO) is an entity that can conduct corporate business without conventional human management. A DAO uses a decentralized network of artificial intelligence (AI) autonomous agents that replicate labor into computational tasks. The agents operate via a set of programmable business rules that often are implemented using publicly auditable open-source software distributed across the computers of their stakeholders.
n.Name: DAO(DistributedAutonomousOrganizations)

n.Vendors: Blackcloud Business Solutions Group; Dato; IBM Watson; Kaggle; SAS Institute; TunedIT
n.Definition: Deep learning is a set of machine-learning algorithms that include various deep neural network models. It is an increasingly popular variant of neural nets, with many more than the typical two processing layers. The additional layers make it possible to identify higher-level abstractions (that is, features) as well as improve classification and prediction accuracy.
n.Name: DeepLearning

n.Vendors: Alpine; Dato; Dell; FICO; IBM (SPSS); Kaggle; Knime; Microsoft; Mu Sigma; Oracle; RapidMiner; RichRelevance; SAP; SAS; Skytree; StatSoft
n.Definition: Ensemble-learning techniques are machine-learning algorithms, where a set of predictive models is created and its outputs combined to become the single output of the entire ensemble. This methodology draws heavily on the "wisdom of the crowd" principle, where the diversification of opinions or model outputs is key. Most well-known patterns of ensemble techniques are random forests and gradient boosting.
n.Name: EnsembleLearning

n.Vendors: 3M Cogent; Cognitec Systems; Eurotech; Facebook; Herta Security; Megvii; NEC; Panasonic; Safran; Samsung; Sensory
n.Definition: Facial recognition is a biometric identification process that matches a scanned image to a known database.
n.Name: FacialRecognition

n.Vendors: Bottomline Technologies; Easy Solutions; EMC (RSA); Forter; Guardian Analytics; iovation; Kaspersky Lab; Kount; Nice Actimize; NuData Security; Sift Science; ThreatMetrix; Trusteer
n.Definition: Fraud detection protects customer and enterprise information, assets, accounts and transactions through real-time, near-real-time or batch analysis of activities by users and other defined entities (such as kiosks). It uses background server-based processes that examine users' and other defined entities' access and behavior patterns and optimally compares this information to a profile of what's expected. Fraud detection is not intrusive to a user unless the user's activity is suspect.
n.Name: FraudDetection

n.Vendors: Enter Vendors
n.Definition: Machines that appear to have capabilities similar to humans in areas such as learning, reasoning, adapting and understanding are labeled intelligent. General-purpose machine intelligence (GPMI), referred to as "Strong AI" by Ray Kurzweil, is applicable to a very broad range of use cases while special-purpose machine intelligence ("Weak AI") is limited to specific (narrower) use cases. Machines with GPMI and the ability to control their own means of maintenance and reproduction exist only in science fiction nightmares.
n.Name: General-PurposeMachineIntelligence

n.Vendors: Digital Field Solutions; Evernote; Microsoft; MyScript; Nokia; Nuance; Paragon Software Group; PhatWare
n.Definition: Handwriting recognition systems use pattern matching to convert handwritten symbols into corresponding computer text or commands in real time. Input device can be a capacitive stylus or finger on premium smartphones, wearables, tablets and PC screens.
n.Name: HandwritingRecognition

n.Vendors: Accenture; Nielsen; Planorama; SAP; Trax Image Recognition
n.Definition: Image recognition, formerly called intelligent image interpretation in our previous Hype Cycles, is a technology that transforms digital images of merchandised product displays, shelf arrangements and planograms captured on a smartphone in-store into usable information and analytics. Pictorial views of the shelf displays and a series of analytics and KPIs are produced to understand shelf conditions, to compare them to contractual agreements and to drive merchandising actions that can lead to increased revenue and consumer satisfaction.
n.Name: ImageRecognition

n.Vendors: Alpine Data Labs; Angoss; BigML; FICO; GE Intelligent Platforms; H2O; IBM; KNIME; Microsoft; SAP; SAS
n.Definition: Machine learning is a discipline that provides computers with the ability to learn from data without being explicitly programmed. Supervised learning aims at learning classifications or estimations, whereas unsupervised learning aims to extract anomalies, patterns and relationships from data via methods such as clustering, dimensionality reduction and density estimation.
n.Name: MachineLearning

n.Vendors: Arria NLG; Automated Insights; BeyondCore; Narrative Science; Yseop
n.Definition: Natural-language generation (NLG) combines natural-language processing (NLP) with machine learning and artificial intelligence to dynamically identify the most relevant insights and context in data (trends, relationships, correlation patterns) and then automatically generate a personalized narrative for each user in their context, to explain meaning or highlight key findings in data.
n.Name: Natural-LanguageGeneration

n.Vendors: 3M Health Information Systems; Atigeo; Dolbey; IBM Watson Health; Linguamatics; Nuance; Qpid Health
n.Definition: Natural-language processing (NLP) technology is used to extract, categorize and summarize data from speech-to-text documents and unstructured clinical documentation. NLP can be used to identify clinical conditions, patient safety issues, quality measures, meaningful use reporting data, procedures for reimbursement and patient populations, such as immigrants, or for point-of-care information delivery for clinical decision support.
n.Name: Natural-LanguageProcessing(ClinicalEnterprise)

n.Vendors: Brainspace; Clarabridge; CognitiveScale; Digital Reasoning; HP Autonomy; IBM Watson; Microsoft; Narrative Science; SAS; Yseop
n.Definition: Natural Language Processing (NLP) consists of those technology categories that:Ease human-computer interaction.Help people find, understand and act on content that exists in their natural language (such as translating, summarizing and synthesizing).Provide the foundation for inferences that make people more effective (such as finding the most likely expert on a subject, or what's trending among their peers).
n.Name: Natural-LanguageProcessing(NLP)

n.Vendors: Apple; Cognitive Code; EasyAsk; Expect Labs; HP; IBM Watson; Microsoft; Nuance; Sherpa Software; Vlingo; Wolfram Research; [24]7
n.Definition: Natural-language question answering (NLQA) technology is composed of applications that provide users with a means of asking a question in plain language. A computer or service can answer it meaningfully, while maintaining the fSmall of interaction.
n.Name: Natural-LanguageQuestionAnswering

n.Vendors: Catalyst; Content Analyst; Everlaw; HP; kCura; Logikcull; Microsoft-Equivio; Recommind
n.Definition: Predictive coding is an embedded capability in e-discovery technology that employs machine learning, applies statistical methods and trains software to classify electronically stored information (ESI). It is used in the review phase of e-discovery and implemented via an iterative workfSmall. It helps reduce the proportion of ESI to be manually reviewed and thus reduces the cost of review, while assuring the defensibility of the e-discovery process.
n.Name: PredictiveCoding

n.Vendors: BioSignia; Munich Re
n.Definition: Predictive underwriting solutions detect patterns in demographic, medical and lifestyle data (in the public domain and privately provided), and use these patterns to build models for underwriting life insurance policies. These solutions can render decisions in seconds, eliminating the need for human underwriters in many decisions, while protecting against anti-selection and assigning specific rate classes.
n.Name: PredictiveUnderwritingSolutions

n.Vendors: AlchemyAPI; Cambridge Semantics; Exaptive; Expert System; HP; Lexalytics; Linguamatics; Ontoforce; Ontotext; OpenAmplify; OpenText; SAS; Semantria; Thomson Reuters
n.Definition: Scientific text analytics and annotators extract data from unstructured scientific text sources. These applications and services aggregate external information and competitive intelligence for use in R&D programs. Text and data are mined and used for summarization, performing sentiment analysis, investigation and classification of data types. These systems are similar to text analytics, but have a focused library and supporting technologies for mining scientific content.
n.Name: ScientificTextAnalyticsandAnnotators

n.Vendors: Almawave; Avaya (Aurix); CallMiner; Genesys (Utopy); HP (Autonomy); Interactive Intelligence; Mattersight; Nexidia; Nice Systems; PBI; Ramp; Raytheon BBN Technologies; Verint Systems; Voci
n.Definition: Audio mining/speech analytics embrace keyword, phonetic or transcription technologies to extract insights from prerecorded and, more recently, real-time voice streams. This insight can then be used to classify calls, trigger alerts/workfSmalls, and drive operational and employee performance across the enterprise.
n.Name: SpeechAnalytics

n.Vendors: Amazon; Apple; Google; IBM; LumenVox; Microsoft; Nuance; Sensory; Spansion; Telisma
n.Definition: Speech recognition systems convert human speech into text or machine instructions.
n.Name: SpeechRecognition

n.DisplayName: Speech Recognition for Contact Center Applications
n.Vendors: Interactions; Microsoft; Nuance Communications; Spoken Communications
n.Definition: Speech recognition technology is used for self-service contact center applications with complex data entry and menu requirements. A directed dialogue application prompts the caller with specific questions and is the most commonly used approach. Natural-language recognition alSmalls open-ended questions to which callers respond with a phrase in their own words. While natural language can make interaction more intuitive, it is more complex to design and deploy.
n.Name: SpeechRecognitionforContactCenterApplications

n.Vendors: Cellictica; Facebook; Google; IBM; Microsoft; Philips; Science Applications International Corp.; SpeechTrans
n.Definition: Speech-to-speech translation involves translating one spoken language into another. It combines speech recognition, machine translation and text-to-speech technology.
n.Name: Speech-to-SpeechTranslation

n.Vendors: Attensity; Clarabridge; HP Autonomy; IBM; IxReveal; Kapiche; KNIME; Megaputer; Microsoft; Nice Systems; OpenText; Oracle; SAP (BusinessObjects); SAS; Temis
n.Definition: Text analytics is the process of deriving information from textual sources. It is used for several purposes, such as summarization (finding the key content in a single document or a larger body of information), sentiment analysis (identifying the nature of commentary on an issue), explication (explaining what is driving that commentary), investigation (discovery of the causes of a specific issue), and classification (of the text's subject or key content).
n.Name: TextAnalytics

n.Vendors: 3VR; Agent Vi; Aimetis; Apical; BRS Labs; Google; iOmniscient; Kai Square; nViso; Nomi; Prism Skylabs; Seedonk; ShopperTrak; Verint Systems; Vidyard; Vocord; YouTube
n.Definition: Industry Analyst defines video analytics (or video content analytics) as a discipline of data science that uses a suite of software tools and techniques to monitor, extract, organize and analyze image streams automatically, in order to identify significant information or events. Video analytics is used in consumer research to generate insight into consumer-buying behavior and to automate and improve the efficiency and speed of video search and analysis.
n.Name: VideoAnalytics

n.Vendors: 3VR; Flex Analytics; HP Autonomy; Koemei; Limelight Networks; LTU technologies; Nexidia; OpenText; Panopto; Ramp; Sonic Foundry; TimeTag
n.Definition: Video search refers to the ability to search within a collection (or "corpus") of videos. Video search incorporates elements of social networking, social tagging, metadata extraction, audio transcription and enterprise search. Audio transcription or phonemic analysis is the most established means of achieving video search, but we expect other factors to become a part of the technology set � which can come from multiple vendors � such as facial recognition and sentiment detection (voice recognition is already used in some cases).
n.Name: VideoSearch

n.Vendors: Automation Anywhere; Blue Prism; Exilant Technologies; Nice Systems
n.Definition: This offering, formerly known as robotic process automation, is a combination of user interface recognition technologies and workfSmall execution. It emulates work of a human agent using screen and keyboard to drive applications and execute system-based work. While called robotic process automation, these tools are not really robots. The tool is not a physical object; it does not typically include artificial intelligence. It is a further stage of automation. Industry Analyst has now introduced a revised technology of virtual business process assistants.
n.Name: VirtualBusinessProcessAssistants

m.Name: VideoSearch
m.Vendors: 3VR; Flex Analytics; HP Autonomy; Koemei; Limelight Networks; LTU technologies; Nexidia; OpenText; Panopto; Ramp; Sonic Foundry; TimeTag
m.Definition: Video search refers to the ability to search within a collection (or "corpus") of videos. Video search incorporates elements of social networking, social tagging, metadata extraction, audio transcription and enterprise search. Audio transcription or phonemic analysis is the most established means of achieving video search, but we expect other factors to become a part of the technology set � which can come from multiple vendors � such as facial recognition and sentiment detection (voice recognition is already used in some cases).
